PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
1.  The proposed project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) to the Uttar Pradesh 
Public Works Department (UPPWD) is required to: 
(i)  Undertake sector preparatory work and define the scope of the ensuing investment 
program; 
(ii)  Prepare the multitranche financing facility (MFF) frameworks, including safeguards 
and  financial  and  economic  viability  assessment  of  the  ensuing  investment 
program; 
(iii)  Assess prioritization of roads for Tranche 1; 
(iv)  Assess  and  strengthen  detailed  project  reports  (DPRs)  for  Tranche  1  roads 
(prepared by UPPWD) for financing by Asian Development Bank (ADB), including 
safeguards  due  diligence,  with  better  project  readiness.  Project  readiness  will 
ensure that project preparation is ready for implementation with feasibility reports, 
safeguards  planning  documents,  DPRs,  and  bidding  documents  prepared  for 
priority roads; 
(v)  Identify capacity development needs of UPPWD in developing and managing state 
roads  in  a  sustainable  manner.  Sustainability  of  road  development  and 
management includes planning capacity, procurement and contract management, 
road asset management, streamlined business process, road safety, environmental 
consideration, and so on; and 
(vi)  Assist the UPPWD in undertaking advance contracting actions for Tranche 1 roads.

C.  Consulting Services 
3.  A firm (or consortium of firms) will be engaged to undertake this PPTA. As estimated, 
this assignment will require 3 international experts for a total of 12 person-months, and 8 
national experts of a total of 28 person-months. The consulting firm will be engaged following 
the  quality-  and  cost-based  selection  method,  with  a  quality–cost  ratio  of  80:20  using full 
technical proposal procedures. Procurement of all consultancy services used under the PPTA 
will be carried out in accordance with ADB‘s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as 
amended from time to time).

4.  The outline terms of reference for the PPTA consultants are described in paras 5 to 15. 
 
D.  Outline Terms of Reference for Key International Experts 
5.  Team Leader/ Highway Engineer. The Team Leader will be a Civil Engineer with 
Masters in Highway or Transportation Engineering, and at least 20 years of experience in the 
highways sector. The Team Leader will provide technical and managerial inputs, as well as 
overall guidance to the PPTA. The Team Leader will coordinate with the UPPWD as well as 
DPR consultants appointed by UPPWD. 
 
6.  Road  Management  &  Institutional  Expert.  The  Road  Management  &  Institutional 
Specialist will be a Civil Engineer with Masters in Highway or Transportation Engineering, and at 
least 15 years experience in maintenance and management of road assets. Experience of 
working with road management systems and institutions will be a requirement. Sustainability of 
road  development  and  management  includes  planning  capacity,  procurement  and  contract 
management,  road  asset  management,  streamlined  business  process,  road  safety,  and 
environmental considerations. The expert will assess, in the context of UPPWD, the existing 
road maintenance and asset management systems, institutional arrangements, staffing and 
budget arrangements, contract management and governance, Based on this assessment, the 
expert will prepare a set of recommendations (financial, institutional, systems) for improving 
road maintenance and asset management systems in the state on a sustainable basis.

3 
 
 
7.  Transport Economist. The Transport Economist will be a Civil Engineer or Economist 
with post-graduate qualifications in transportation or transportation economics and at least 15 
years experience in the sector. The economist will undertake economic and financial viability 
analysis of the proposed investment program and Tranche 1 roads, drawing from existing data. 
 
E.  Outline Terms of Reference for Key National Experts 
8.  Highway Design Engineer. The Highway Design Engineer will be a graduate in civil 
engineering, with at least 12 years experience in design of roads and highways. The engineer 
will be responsible for reviewing the DPRs prepared by UPPWD, and in assessing the technical 
feasibility,  costing,  and  other  engineering  details  of  the  project  roads  and  planned 
improvements.  The  engineer  will  assess  the  vulnerability  of  the  proposed  road  options  to 
climate  change,  and  propose  measures for  climate  proofing  design  options for roads  and 
structures.1 
 
9.  Bridge  Engineer.  The  Bridge  Engineer  will  be  a  Civil  Engineer,  with  Masters  in 
structural engineering and at least 12 years experience in design of bridges for transportation 
projects. The engineer will be responsible for reviewing the DPRs prepared by UPPWD, and in 
assessing the technical feasibility, costing, and other engineering details of the bridges and 
structures on the project roads. The engineer will also provide inputs to the climate resilient 
design for longitudinal and cross drainage structures. 
 
10.  Pavement/ Materials Engineer. The Pavement/ Materials Engineer will be a graduate 
in civil engineering, with at least 12 years experience in design of pavements and material 
engineering for road projects. The engineer will be responsible for reviewing the DPRs prepared 
by UPPWD, and in assessing the technical feasibility, costing, and other engineering details of 
the pavement designs and bases on the project roads. 
 
11.  Geotechnical  Engineer.  The  Geotechnical  Engineer  will  be  a  graduate  in  civil 
engineering, with at least 12 years experience in geotechnical investigations and designs for 
transportation projects. The engineer will be responsible for reviewing the DPRs prepared by 
UPPWD, and in assessing the technical feasibility, costing, and other engineering details of the 
geotechnical aspects for the project roads. 
 
12.  Procurement Expert. The Procurement Expert will be a graduate in civil engineering, 
with at least 12 years experience in procurement for infrastructure projects. The expert is 
required to be familiar with ADB’s procurement guidelines. The expert will be responsible for 
assessing  UPPWD’s  capacity  in  carrying  out  procurement  as  per  ADB’s  procurement 
guidelines. The expert will assist UPPWD in advance procurement, including preparation of 
procurement plan, procurement packaging, procurement documents, technical schedules, etc., 
to attain a high level of readiness to bid. If required, the expert should also review the e-
procurement system being followed in the state. 
 
13.  Institutional Finance Expert. The Institutional Financial Expert will be a Chartered 
Accountant or Masters in Business Administration with finance and accounting, with at least 12 
years experience in financial management, audit, and accounts for public sector institutions. 
The expert will undertake a governance (financial management, institutional) appraisal of the

UPPWD and a fiscal assessment of the state of Uttar Pradesh, from available data. Based on 
the assessment, the expert will recommend measures to strengthen specific areas, in the 
context of the Program. 
 
14.  Environmental Safeguards Expert. The Environmental Safeguards Expert will be a 
graduate in environmental engineering, civil engineering or other related fields. The expert will 
have  at  least  8  years  experience  of  having  undertaken  environmental  assessment  for 
infrastructure projects comprising roads and transportation projects, and conversant with ADB’s 
requirements under Safeguards Policy Statement (2009). The expert will assess the Tranche 1 
roads through EIA/ IEE (as the case may be) and develop the environmental assessment and 
review framework for the proposed investment program. 
 
15.  Social & Gender Expert. The Social & Gender Expert will be a graduate sociology, or 
other  relevant  fields.  The  expert  will  have  at  least  8  years  experience  of  dealing  with 
rehabilitation and resettlement matters, working with social groups and communities, livelihood 
aspects, and gender concerns. The expert will have familiarity with ADB’s requirements under 
Safeguards Policy Statement (2009), for road and highway projects. The expert will assess the 
Tranche  1  roads,  prepare  a  resettlement  plan  as  required,  and  develop  the  resettlement 
framework and indigenous peoples planning framework for the proposed investment program. 
The expert will review existing social & community aspects of the project, poverty, employment 
and literacy data, and determine employment benefits and potential labor impacts. The expert 
will  also  assess  any  poverty  and  gender-related  matters  relating  to  Tranche  1  roads  and 
prepare appropriate plans, including a Gender Action Plan, for feasible interventions to improve 
these aspects of the project design. This gender analysis will build on preliminary gender issues 
which are mentioned in the IPSA, such as possible employment during construction and for 
ongoing maintenance. 
 
F.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  UPPWD will be the PPTA executing agency. It will provide in-kind contributions in the 
form of counterpart staff, office accommodation, office supplies, and communication facilities for 
consultants.  PPTA  consultants  will  be  mobilized  in  a  staggered  manner  with  a  focus  on 
preparing the Program, prioritizing and preparing Tranche 1 roads, and facilitating advance 
actions to achieve project readiness. 
 
17.  Disbursements under the TA will be done in accordance with the ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Handbook (May 2010, as amended).
